title: Competition

articles.content: Competition is a by-product of productive work, not its goal. A creative man is motivated by the desire to achieve, not by the desire to beat others.
articles.attribution:
“The Moratorium on Brains,”
The Ayn Rand Letter, I, 2, 4

articles.content:
A competition presupposes some basic principles held in common by all the
competitors, such as the rules of the game in athletics, or the functions of
the free market in business.

The only actual factor required for the existence of free competition is: the unhampered, unobstructed operation of the mechanism of a free market. The only action which a government can take to protect free competition is: Laissez-faire!—which, in free translation, means: Hands off! But the antitrust laws established exactly opposite conditions—and achieved the exact opposite of the results they had been intended to achieve.
articles.attribution:
“America’s Persecuted Minority: Big Business,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 54

articles.content: The concept of free competition enforced by law is a grotesque contradiction in terms. It means: forcing people to be free at the point of a gun. It means: protecting people’s freedom by the arbitrary rule of unanswerable bureaucratic edicts.
articles.attribution:
“America’s Persecuted Minority: Big Business,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 52

articles.content:
Competition, properly so-called, rests on the activity of separate, independent
individuals owning and exchanging private property in the pursuit of their
self-interest.  It arises when two or more such individuals become rivals for
the same trade.
articles.attribution:
George Reisman, “Platonic Competition,”
The Objectivist, Aug. 1968, 9

articles.content:
The competition which takes place under capitalism acts to regulate prices
simply in accordance with the full costs of production and with the
requirements of earning a rate of profit.  It does not act to drive prices to
the level of “marginal costs” or to the point where they reflect a “scarcity”
of capacity.
articles.attribution:
George Reisman, “Platonic Competition,”
The Objectivist, Aug. 1968, 11

articles.content:
The competitor who cuts his price is fully aware of the impact on other
competitors and that they will try to match his price.  He acts in the
knowledge that some of them will not be able to afford the cut, while he is,
and that he will eventually pick up their business.  He is able to afford the
cut when and if his productive efficiency is greater than theirs, which lowers
his costs to a level they cannot match . . . . Thus price competition, under
capitalism, is the result of a contest of efficiency, competence, ability.
articles.attribution:
George Reisman, “Platonic Competition,”
The Objectivist, Sept. 1968, 9

articles.content:
“Competition” is an active, not a passive, noun.  It applies to the entire
sphere of economic activity, not merely to production, but also to trade; it
implies the necessity of taking action to affect the conditions of the market
in one’s own favor.
articles.attribution:
Alan Greenspan, “Antitrust,”
Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal, 67
